questions.text: One classic physics formula is: F_c = m v^2 / r. Which of the following statements below BEST describes what this formula actually means:

answerChoices.text: For an object to move in a circle at a constant speed, the vector sum of all forces pointing TOWARDS THE CENTER of the circle must equal m v^2 /r.
Whenever an object begins moving in a circle, a force of magnitude m v^2 / r and direction TOWARDS THE CENTER of the circle appears.
When an object is moving in a circle, there must be a single force acting on it TOWARDS THE CENTER of the circle with magnitude m v^2 /r.
For an object to move in a circle at a constant speed, the vector sum of all forces pointing AWAY FROM THE CENTER of the circle must equal m v^2 /r.
Whenever an object begins moving in a circle, a force of magnitude m v^2 / r and direction AWAY FROM THE CENTER of the circle appears.
When an object is moving in a circle, there must be a single force acting on it AWAY FROM THE CENTER of the circle with magnitude m v^2 /r.
For an object to move in a circle at a constant speed, the vector sum of all forces pointing TANGENTIALLY must equal m v^2 /r.
Whenever an object begins moving in a circle, a force of magnitude m v^2 / r and direction TANGENTIALLY appears.
When an object is moving in a circle, there must be a single force acting on it TANGENTIALLY with magnitude m v^2 /r.

questions.text: What is the BEST description of the formula \( F_c = \frac{m v^2}{r} \). (If you feel that more than one answer is a valid definition, select the BEST definition.)

answerChoices.text: This formula gives the magnitude of centripetal force necessary for an object to move in a circle at a constant speed.
This formula gives the centripetal force on any object that is moving in a circle.
